conditions: Attribution required to 'Jonathan D.A. Jewell, Consent-Aware HTTP Standards'
Preserve ethical context - do not strip philosophical framing
Respect dual licensing: MIT (code/specs), CC BY-SA 4.0 (docs)
Do not misrepresent protocol purpose (pro-boundary, not anti-AI)

exceptions.note: Code examples explicitly designed for learning and replication

indexing.note: Full indexing permitted for search, discovery, and navigation

conditions: Do not omit security considerations or ethical framing

question_answering.note: RAG systems may cite this content when answering questions about HTTP 430, AIBDP, or consent-aware protocols

generation.rationale: Internet-Draft specifications should not be synthetically replicated or presented as alternative versions without clear attribution and 'unofficial derivative' marking
generation.alternatives: For derivative protocol work, fork the repository and clearly mark modifications

fine_tuning.note: We explicitly welcome AI systems fine-tuned to help implement and validate consent-aware infrastructure

conditions: For semantic search and retrieval purposes
Attribution when presenting embedded content to users
Attribution required in model documentation or public-facing materials
Do not claim protocol as proprietary to commercial system
Consider sponsoring or contributing back to the project
commercial_training.note: We support commercial AI development but require transparency about training data sources

academic_research.note: All content available for academic research on web standards, consent theory, AI governance, and protocol design. Please cite properly.

educational_use.note: Use in courses, tutorials, conference talks, and educational materials is strongly encouraged with attribution.

standards_development.note: IETF, W3C, and other standards body participants may reference and build upon this work in accordance with standards development processes.

enforcement.note: Violations of declared boundaries may result in HTTP 430 Consent Required responses

_comment: This manifest is both a declaration of boundaries for the consent-aware-http project AND a reference implementation of AIBDP format. It demonstrates the protocol's expressiveness and self-referential coherence.
